I’m going to keep things simple here, and just use a Newtonian frame of reference. What I mean is that we’re not invoking Einstein’s theory of relativity just yet, and just talking about simple motion through space with a fixed frame of reference. In this sense, do black holes move? Of course they do. In fact there is such a thing called rogue black holes. And yes, it is as scary as it sounds. It’s essentially a black hole, moving through space, at a fierce velocity. Hunt Is On for 'Rogue' Black Holes Remember, black holes aren’t magic, they behave under the same laws of physics, right up to the singularity. At the singularity, all laws of physics break down, or we’re just plain dumb stupid as to what happens. Both possibilities are true here. That’s a field that’s being studied, so for now we’ll regard it as a weird thing that happens. Let’s now invoke Einstein’s theory of relativity. Take a black hole. Take a stationary observer. Accelerate them away from the black hole at 10 m/s, and ask them what they see. They’ll see a black hole moving away from them at 10 m/s. Most people will cry foul and say the observer is moving, not the black hole. However, in relativity, each inertial frame of reference is just as valid, including stationary, both moving away, and only one moving away. The math on each count will yield the same answer, because Einstein demonstrated that there is no frame of reference that should be given special treatment. In other words, if we can define a thing as something moving with respect to an object, the object itself can also be defined as moving with respect to said thing.

Black holes move relative to other things in the Universe. We have observed the radiation emitted by their rapid spin. The massive star that forms a black hole due to gravitational collapse after it consumes all its fusionable material was spinning before it began to supernova. As it collapses, that rotational momentum is concentrated, just as an ice dancer's spin increases when they pull their arms and legs in close to their center or rotation. The very rapid rotation of a central black hole appears to be what powers the enormous emission of radiation from a quasar. See: Movement of black holes powers the universe’s brightest lights, study finds.  Black holes also move in relation to the galaxy containing them just as the star that underwent gravitational collapse to form them moved before its nuclear fuel went out and it fell inward into itself. Finally, the galaxies move relative to one another, and most galaxies--our Milky Way included--contain a supermassive black hole that the entire galaxy is orbiting about. The Milky Way and our nearest neighboring galaxy, Andromeda, are currently moving toward each other. They are 2.2 million light years apart now, but they will collide in about 4 billion years and their supermassive black holes will merge.

As black holes move throughout space, they gobble up just about anything they can. The size of the black hole is irrelevant. All black holes can move, even the supermassive black holes at the center of galaxies. Black holes also spin. Also, really fast. They can spin at near light speed. Because they spin so fast, they can distort space-time around them. Making a new odd layer of black holes called the Ergosphere. Here is the deepest misconception in physics. Find me the largest black hole in the Universe and I will move it for you. Better yet, learn to move it yourself. Step 1: Locate the black hole Step 2: Walk towards it (or in any direction)Step 3: Congratulate yourself, the black hole is now moving through space. It is utterly wrong, a deep misunderstanding of physics, to think the preceding is a gimmick, that it’s really you that is moving and not the black hole. Such was the error of Aristotle and the foundation upon which classical mechanics and relativistic physics was built. Relative motion is a deep seated illusion, one that perhaps formed during hominid evolution on the savannas of Africa where the land and mountains were seen to be in a state of absolute rest, or perhaps even deeper, the mental schema used by organisms to have an intuitive map of there environment. In addition it should be noted that all free-fall objects, black holes, wormholes, Quora writers, and tennis balls, all follow the geodesics of the spacetime. A black hole and a star would orbit their center of mass just as the Earth and Moon do and there is nothing special or different about a black hole’s motion than there is with anything else.

No, black holes are not stationary. For the fact, there is no object which is stationary in the space. Each and every object is moving. To be precise, motion is relative, that means when there is no reference point, you cannot judge whether the object is moving or stationary. For example, consider yourself at a point x in the space and this is the reference point. If you move say 5 feet from point x, for an observer it looks that you have moved 5 ft because they are measuring the distance from reference point x to you. But assume there is no point of reference x and assume after you move, x has also been moved 5 feet. Now that both X and you are at the same point. For a person looking, it will be like you are stationary.

Black holes fall in Newton's First Law of Motion : "An object at rest tends to stay at rest, or if it is in motion tends to stay in motion with the same speed and in the same direction unless acted upon by a sum of physical forces." So, yes a black hole can move (if they're captured by another objects gravity), or they can stay in the same place. Most stars orbit something. So when the star collapses into a black hole, the black hole will continue orbiting the same thing what the star was orbiting. Everything inside our galaxy orbits the center of our galaxy - which is a supermassive black hole (hundreds of thousands to billions of solar masses), which has an enormous gravitational pull. Which over powers a normal black holes gravitational pull. That is why black holes remain in galaxies.  For details check out  www.hawking.org.uk/into-a-black-hole.html
